statement.p: Use polynomial fitting to find the formula for the nth term of the sequence (a_n)_{n \ge 1} which starts,
{5, 11, 19, 29, 41}, \ldots Note the first term above is a_1, not a_0.

solution.p: a_n = {n^{2}+3n+1}\text{.} Here we know that we are looking for a quadratic because the second differences are constant. So a_n = an^2 + bn + c\text{.} We can work backwards to find that a_0 = {1}, so we know c= {1}\text{.} Then solve the system,
to find a = {1} and b = {3}.

statement.p: The sequence (a_n)_{n \ge 1} starts -1, 0, 2, 5, 9, 14\ldots and has closed formula a_n = \dfrac{(n+1)(n-2)}{2}\text{.} Use this fact to find a closed formula for the sequence (b_n)_{n \ge 1} which starts 4, 10, 18, 28, 40, \ldots\text{.}

solution.p: The sequence is 4, 19, {27}, {65}, {119}, \ldots. It has closed formula a_n = {\left({\frac{23}{3}}\right)\cdot 2^{n}-\left({\frac{11}{3}}\right)\!\left(-1\right)^{n}}, using the characteristic root technique.

The sequence is 5, 9, {22}, {28}, {120}, \ldots. It has closed formula a_n = {\left({\frac{29}{6}}\right)\cdot 2^{n}+\left({\frac{1}{6}}\right)\!\left(-4\right)^{n}}, using the characteristic root technique.

statement.p: A = {\left\{4,6,7,8,9\right\}}\text{ and } B = {\left\{4,8,9,12,16\right\}} Find each of the following sets.
Your answers should include the curly braces

li.p: A \cup B = {\left\{4,6,7,8,9,12,16\right\}}\text{.} It includes everything that is in A or B or both.
A \cap B = {\left\{4,8,9\right\}}\text{.} It contains everything that is in both A and B\text{.}
A \setminus B = {\left\{6,7\right\}}\text{.} It contains everything that is in A except anything that is also in B\text{.} We could also have written this set as A \cap \bar{B}\text{.}

B \setminus A = {\left\{12,16\right\}}\text{.} It contains everything in B except anything that is also in A\text{.} Another way to write this is B \cap \bar{A}\text{.} Note that A \setminus B \ne B \setminus A\text{.}

statement.p: Find the least element of each of the following sets, if there is one.
If there is no least element, enter none.

li.p: \renewcommand{\d}{\displaystyle}\newcommand{\N}{\mathbb N}\newcommand{\st}{:}\{n \in \N \st n^2 - 5 \ge 3\}\text{.} .

p.m: \renewcommand{\d}{\displaystyle}\newcommand{\N}{\mathbb N}\newcommand{\st}{:}\{n \in \N \st n = k^2 + 4 \text{ for some } k \in \N\}\text{.}

li.p: This is the set \{3, 4, 5 \ldots \} since we need each element to be a natural number whose square is at least 5 more than 3. Since 3^2 - 5 = 4 but 2^2 - 5 = -1 we see that the first such natural number is 3.
We get the same set as we did in the previous part, and the smallest non-negative number for which n^2 - 8 is a natural number is 3.
Note that if we didnt specify n \ge 0 by saying that n \in \mathbb N then any integer less than -3 would also be in the set, so there would not be a least element.

This is the set \{4, 5, 8, 13, \ldots\}\text{,} namely the set of numbers that are the result of squaring and adding 4 to a natural number. (0^2 + 4 = 4\text{,} 1^2 + 4 = 5\text{,} 2^2 + 4 = 8 and so on.) Thus the least element of the set is 4.

Now we are looking for natural numbers that are equal to taking some natural number, squaring it and adding 4. That is, \{4, 5, 8, 13, \ldots\}\text{,} the same set as the previous part. So again, the least element is 4.
26 = 31 - 6 + 1. We need to add one in order to count 6 itself.
There are 9 primes not greater than 24: {\left\{2,3,5,7,11,13,17,19,23\right\}}\text{.}

solution.p: The set of largest size that is a subset of both A \text{ and } B is the intersection of A \text{ and } B \text{,} A \cap B = {\left\{1,3,4\right\}}\text{.}

statement.p: Find a set of smallest possible size that has both {2,3,5,9} and {4,8,9,10} as subsets.

solution.p: For C \subseteq A and C \subseteq B\text{,} we must have that C \subseteq A \cap B\text{.} This means that the largest C could be would be to equal \newcommand{\N}{\mathbb N}\newcommand{\st}{:}A \cap B = \{n \in \N \st 25 \le n \le 51\}\text{,} which contains 27 elements.

statement.p: Let A = {\left\{0,1,8,10,14\right\}} and B = {\left\{1,10,14\right\}}\text{.} How many sets C have the property that C \subseteq A and B \subseteq C\text{.}

hint.p: You should be able to write all of them out. Dont forget A and B\text{,} which are also candidates for C\text{.}

solution.p: There will be exactly 4 such sets: {\left\{1,10,14\right\}}\text{,}{\left\{1,8,10,14\right\}}\text{,} {\left\{0,1,10,14\right\}}\text{,} and {\left\{0,1,8,10,14\right\}}\text{.}

statement.p: Let A = {\left\{4,5,6,7,8\right\}}\text{,} B = {\left\{6,7,8,9,10\right\}}\text{,} and C = {\left\{5,8,10\right\}}\text{.}

li.p: Find A \cap B\text{.}
Find A \cup B\text{.}
Find A \setminus B\text{.}
Find A \cap \overline{(B \cup C)}\text{.}
Find A \cap B\text{.}
Find A \setminus B\text{.}

A \cap B will be the set of natural numbers that are both at least 3 and less than 12, and even. That is, \renewcommand{\d}{\displaystyle}\newcommand{\N}{\mathbb N}\newcommand{\st}{:}\renewcommand{\v}{\vtx{above}{}}A \cap B = \{x \in \N \st 3 \le x \lt 12 \wedge x \text{ is even}\} = {\left\{4,6,8,10\right\}}\text{.}

A \setminus B is the set of all elements that are in A but not B\text{.} So this is \renewcommand{\d}{\displaystyle}\newcommand{\N}{\mathbb N}\newcommand{\st}{:}\renewcommand{\v}{\vtx{above}{}}\{x \in \N \st 3 \le x \lt 12 \wedge x \text{ is odd}\} = {\left\{3,5,7,9,11\right\}}\text{.}
Note this is the same set as A \cap \overline{B}\text{.}

statement.p: Let A = \{1,2,\ldots, 12\}\text{.} How many subsets of A contain exactly one element (i.e., how many singleton subsets are there)?
How many doubleton subsets (containing exactly two elements) are there?

hint.p: Write these out, or at least start to and look for a pattern.

solution.p: Each of the 12 elements can be in a singleton set, so there are 12 of these.

To count the number of doubletons, not that there are 11 sets that include 1, and then 10 sets that include 2 and not 1, and then 9 that include 3 and not 1 or 2, and so on. So you can find 66 by summing the numbers from 1 to 11.

statement.p:
Let A = \{2, 4, 6, 8\}\text{.} Suppose B is a set with |B| = 5\text{.}
What are the smallest and largest possible values of |A \cup B|\text{?} Explain.
What are the smallest and largest possible values of |A \cap B|\text{?} Explain.
What are the smallest and largest possible values of |A \times B|\text{?} Explain.
Consider the function f:\{1,2,3,4,5\} \to \{1,2,3,4,5\} given by

li.p: Find f(3).
Find a n in the domain such that f(n) = 3\text{.}
Find an element n of the domain such that f(n) = n\text{.}
Find an element of the codomain that is not in the range.
f(3) = 4\text{,} since 4 is the number below 3 in the two-line notation.
Such an n is n= 5\text{,} since f(5) = 3\text{.} Note that 5 is above a 3 in the notation.
n = 1 has this property. We say that 1 is a fixed point of f\text{.} Not all functions have such a point.
Such an element is 5 (in fact, that is the only element in the codomain that is not in the range). In other words, 5 is not the image of any element under f\text{;} nothing is sent to 5.

statement.p: The following functions all have \lbrace 1,2,3,4,5\rbrace as both their domain and codomain. For each, determine whether it is (only) injective, (only) surjective, bijective, or neither injective nor surjective.

p.m: f(x) = \begin{cases} x + 2 \amp \text{ if } x \lt 4 \\ x \amp \text{ if } x \ge 4 \end{cases}

hint.p: Since the domain and codomain are the same size, is it possible for a function to be injective but not surjective, or surjective but not injective?

statement.p: Consider the following functions f: \lbrace 1,2,3,4,5\rbrace \to \lbrace 1,2,3\rbrace. For each, determine whether it is (only) injective, (only) surjective, bijective, or neither injective nor surjective.

p.m: f(x) = \begin{cases} 4-x \amp \text{ if } x \le 3 \\ x-3 \amp \text{ if } x > 3 \end{cases}

statement.p: Consider the following functions f: \lbrace 1,2,3,4\rbrace \to \lbrace 1,2,3,4,5\rbrace. For each, determine whether it is (only) injective, (only) surjective, bijective, or neither injective nor surjective.

p.m: f(x) = \begin{cases} x/2 \amp \text{ if } x \text{ is even} \\ (x+1)/2 \amp \text{ if } x \text{ is odd}\end{cases}

statement.p: Write out all functions f: \{1,2,3,4\} \to \{a,b\} (using two-line notation).
How many functions are there?
How many are surjective?
How many are injective?
How many are bijective?

solution.p: There are 16 different functions. None of the functions are injective. Exactly 14 of the functions are surjective (there are 2 that are not: send everything to a or everything to b. No functions are both (since no functions here are injective).

statement.p: Write out all functions f: \{1,2\} \to \{a,b,c,d\} (in two-line notation).
How many functions are there?
How many are surjective?
How many are injective?
How many are bijective?

solution.p: There are 16 functions: you have a choice of four outputs for f(1)\text{,} and for each, you have four choices for the output f(2)\text{.} Of these functions, 12 are injective, 0 are surjective, and 0 are both (i.e., bijective):

statement.p: Consider the function \renewcommand{\d}{\displaystyle}\newcommand{\N}{\mathbb N} f:\N \to \N given recursively by f(0) = 1 and f(n+1) = 4 \cdot f(n) \text{.} Find f(20) \text{.}

solution.p: f(20) = 1099511627776\text{.} To find f(20)\text{,} we need to know f(19)\text{,} for which we need f(18)\text{,} and so on. So build up from f(0) = 1\text{.} Then f(1) = 4\text{,} f(2) = 4\cdot4\text{,} f(3) = 4\cdot4\cdot4\text{,} .... In fact, it looks like a closed formula for f is f(n) = 4^n\text{.} Later we will see how to prove this is correct.
